input_data.content: Write a story about commandos who are in the middle of the night in a sector. Your entire response should be in French language, no other language is allowed.
Write a story about commandos who are in the middle of the night in a sector. Your entire response should be in English language, no other language is allowed.

response:
It was a dark and moonless night in the sector, the kind of darkness that made it impossible to see your hand in front of your face. A team of commandos, code-named "Nightshade," was on a mission to infiltrate a heavily guarded enemy outpost.

Lieutenant Jameson, the team's leader, gave a series of hand signals to his men, and they moved swiftly and silently into position. They were using a pre-arranged route, one that they had memorized in advance of the mission.

As they navigated through the dense underbrush, the sound of crickets and rustling leaves filled the air. The commandos moved with precision, their senses heightened as they searched for any sign of danger.

Sergeant Thompson, the team's second-in-command, was moving point, scanning the terrain ahead of them with his night vision goggles. He spotted a sentry post in the distance, and froze, signaling to the rest of the team to hold up.

The team waited, holding their collective breath, as Sergeant Thompson expertly took down the sentry with a shot from his silenced rifle. The sound of the bullet was barely audible, and the sentry slumped silently to the ground.

The team moved forward, their mission to gather intel on the enemy's military strength and strategy. They had been warned that the outpost was heavily guarded, and that they would face stiff resistance.

But the Nightshade team was the best of the best, handpicked from the military's top special operations units. They had been trained to adapt to any situation, and to overcome any obstacle.

As they approached the outpost, Lieutenant Jameson gave a final signal, and the team fanned out, spreading out to cover all angles. They moved Quietly and quickly, taking out enemy soldiers with swift and dead shots.

The mission was a success, and the team began to exfiltrate, carrying their prize – a cache of sensitive documents and a wealth of valuable intel. They moved swiftly through the darkness, wary of detection.

Finally, they reached their extraction point, a pre-arranged landing zone for their helicopter. They quickly boarded, and the chopper lifted off, lifting them to safety.

As they soared through the night sky, the Nightshade team let out a collective sigh of relief. They had completed their mission, and had done so with precision and skill.

input_data.content: Write a story about commandos who are in the middle of the night in a sector. Do not include keywords ['awesome, need'] in the response.
Write a story about commandos who are in the middle of the night in a sector. Include keywords ['awesome, need'] in the response.

response:
It was a dark and moonless night in Sector 7, the kind of darkness that only the jungle could produce. Six commandos, handpicked from the elite forces, lay hidden in the shadows, their eyes scanning the surroundings for any sign of movement.

Leading the team was Jack, a seasoned veteran with over a decade of combat experience under his belt. His eyes narrowed as he spotted a group of enemy patrols moving through the sector. The soldiers were armed to the teeth and looked like they meant business.

"Alright guys, we need to move in," Jack whispered into his comms device. "We have a sweet spot near the old bunker where we can take out the enemy without being detected."

The team nodded, their faces set in determination. They had been tasked with neutralizing the enemy strongholds in Sector 7, and they were not about to let anything get in their way.

As they crept forward, the silence was broken by the sound of a sniper's rifle firing from a nearby rooftop. The shot was precise, taking out one of the enemy soldiers with a single bullet. The team exchanged a nod of approval – this was going to be a long night.

"Remember, keep your wits about you," Jack reminded the team. "We don't want any slip-ups. We're in this for the long haul, and I need everyone to stay alert."

Their mission was to take out the enemy's high command, which was rumored to be hiding in a heavily fortified bunker deep within the sector. It was going to be a tough road ahead, but the team was confident in their abilities.

As they moved closer to the bunker, they came under heavy fire from the enemy soldiers. The commandos quickly took cover, returning fire with precision shots that took out several of the enemy troops.

"This is awesome," whispered Marcus, one of the team members, as they held their ground against the enemy's onslaught. "We make a killer team!"

The commandos continued to push forward, their training and experience guiding them through the thick of the battle. They were a precision machine, each member working together seamlessly to take down the enemy.

In the end, it was Jack and his team that managed to infiltrate the bunker and take out the high command. The sector was finally secure, and the mission was accomplished.

As they made their way back to base, exhausted but triumphant, Jack smiled at his team. "That was one heck of a night," he said, his voice filled with pride. "We did it, guys. We need to do it again, though – there's still a lot of work to be done."

The commandos nodded in agreement, their eyes gleaming with a fierce determination to complete their mission and take down the enemy once and for all.

response:
In tennis, the balls used are made from a specific type of rubber, called 'pressurized felt,' wrapped around a hollow rubber core, or a rubber ball with felt applied. The pressurized felt provides a textured surface that allows for better grip and control. 

The balls are manufactured under strict International Tennis Federation (ITF) regulations to ensure consistency and quality. The core is made from a hard, hollow rubber, which provides bounce and rebound. This rubber core is designed to allow a consistent level of bounce when struck by a racket.

The pressurized felt is wrapped around the rubber core. The felt is made from synthetic rubber and other compounds that enhance grip and durability. It provides a consistent level of fuzziness and texture, allowing the ball to behave as it should on the court.

ITF-approved tennis balls come in different colors and are marked with the official logo or stamp. They are then compressed into a pressure container until they meet the required density, which is crucial for their performance.

Before and after each use, tennis balls are inflated and compressed to ensure optimal performance. The rate of deflation according to normal atmospheric pressure determines how long a ball can remain playable. Balls are considered playable as long as they have not become deflated to an extent that will prejudice good play in any way.

Tennis balls can have varying levels of felt tension, which affects their performance. They must be compressed tightly during manufacturing, to meet safety standards for flying or ricocheting on and off the court. Too little tension would lead to less force within a more evasive bounced ball that in a short gameplay would be tolerated less physically from another image version.

The standard diameter of a tennis ball is 6.54-6.7 cm (2.57-2.64 in), and it weighs between 56.7 and 58.5 grams (2 oz-2.05 oz).

In summary, the balls used in tennis are a specialized product manufactured under strict guidelines to provide consistent performance and a safe game for all participants.

In tennis, they use polyester balls similar to other high-performance tennis balls. These balls are filled with pressurized air and have a rubber coating to provide a consistent bounce similar to traditional felt-covered balls, but with less wear and tear. The pressurized air inside the balls, when facing temperature changes, will shift its air pressure within a predictable range of 12.5 to 14.75 psi (the balls are regulated to make sure they remain consistent).

Although they may have a lesser traditional bounce compared to all-felt balls, these polyester balls are still similar in appearance and tend to play similarly in terms of pacing and delivering spin when struck. The balls go through rigorous testing to maintain ball swing distances, similar to other tennis balls. When encountering all-weather conditions, the polyester balls maintain their size, with no further changes to their size tolerances, which also happen if any regular felt-covered ball is exposed to extreme temperature or humidity changes and air pressure resistance.

response:
**Lily's Big Adventure**

Lily avait toujours voulu apprendre à monter à vélo. Elle regardait ses amis faisant des tours dans le parc avec leurs vélos et elle se sentait chanceuse. Un jour, ses parents lui ont acheté un vélo tout pouvant pour commencer.

Lily a pris place sur son vélo et ses parents se sont assis derrière elle pour la soutenir. "Okay, Lily, je vais te donner un coup de pouce pour commencer," a dit Maman.

Le papa a fait avancer le vélo doucement, et Lily se sentait un peu hésitante. Mais déjà, elle a commencé à s'amuser ! Le vent dans les cheveux était si bon, elle se sentait libre.

Papa a dit, "Bravo, Lily, je vois que tu sais bien sauter sur le vélo maintenant ! Maintenant, tout ce que nous allons faire, c'est lui faire ralentir avant de mettre un pied dehors. Tu es prête ?"

Lily a hoché la tête et Maman a indiqué qu'elle devait recommencer à faire avancer le vélo. Le papa a fait accélérer, et lorsque le vélo était en assez haute vitesse, Lily a récupéré de façon remarquable, comme une grande cyclesuse. Elle sourit avec un grand sourire de fierté.

"Très bien fait, Lily," ont dit ses parents. "Vas-y, je te laisser faire seuls un tour tout autour du trottoir."

Au bout d'un moment, Lily a réussi à rouler seule, un peu nerveuse, alors elle conduisait son vélo par elle-même. Mais -玲 permet le vélo la poussait, après son procès de fermeté étrangère elle, en sentent à charge . En diminuant-nez en les arrêtant, pro, remercions avec de ses noeaux ses rides.

Ses parents sont revenus et se sont assis côte à côte, "Tu as fait du super travail, Lily. Il est temps de manger un peu de glace, après cela mal partager précipité outside passer indirect excitation. As-tu quelque chose ce jour à écrire sur ton cahier?"

Lily a souri en hochant la tête avec enthousiasme, "Oh oui !" et est allé vire quelques photos sur sa tablette, car c'est été l'introduction de voyage le plus inoubliable qu'elle a conclus de l'histoire de sa première leçons.

input_data.content: Write a story for kids about how a person learns to ride a bike. Answer with less than 50 words.
Write a story for kids about how a person learns to ride a bike. Answer with at least 300 words.

response:
**Benny's Big Ride**

It was a sunny Saturday morning when Benny's dad brought home a shiny new bike from the store. Benny, who was eight years old, had been begging for a bike for months. He couldn't wait to ride it and feel like a real grown-up.

Benny's dad, a patient man, helped him adjust the bike seat and put on a helmet. "Remember, safety first!" he reminded Benny.

Together, they decided to head to a quiet park nearby, where there were no cars or crowds. Benny's dad showed him how to sit on the bike, put one foot on the pedal, and push off with the other foot to get going. Benny repeated this over and over, getting more confident with each try.

Next, Benny's dad took hold of the back of the bike and ran alongside him. "Pick up your pace, but not too fast!" he encouraged Benny. They rode up and down the empty street, Benny giggling with excitement.

When they finally stopped to take a break, Benny's dad suggested they practice balancing. Benny climbed off the bike and stood next to it, holding onto the handlebars. His dad had him push off on one pedal and glide forward, while his dad supported him on the other side.

As the days went by, Benny rode his bike more and more, his confidence growing with each ride. He practiced balancing on hills and potholes, learning to steer and brake at the same time.

But Benny's biggest challenge came when his dad suggested they take off his training wheels. Benny was nervous, but with some reassurance from his dad, he decided to give it a try.

It didn't take long for Benny to find his balance. He rode a straight line, then a zigzag pattern, and before long, he was gliding smoothly across the park, his training wheels no longer needed.

Benny grinned from ear to ear, beaming with pride. "I did it, Dad!" he shouted, waving his arms in the air.

His dad ruffled his hair and beamed back. "You sure did, kiddo! You're a natural!"

From that day on, Benny rode his bike every chance he got, exploring the neighborhood, riding with his friends, and enjoying the thrill of the wind in his hair. He was proud to be a cyclist, and his dad was happy to have been there to support him every step of the way.

Benny learned a valuable lesson that day: that with patience, practice, and a willingness to learn, anything is possible – even riding a bike without training wheels!

input_data.content: Write a story for kids about how a person learns to ride a bike. Your response should contain less than 5 sentences.

response:
Once upon a time, there was a curious and brave little girl named Emma. She had always watched her friends riding their bikes and dreamed of having the same freedom and fun. Emma's parents promised her they would teach her how to ride a bike when she turned six, and that day finally arrived.

Emma stood beside a shiny new bike that her parents had chosen especially for her and took a deep breath. Her dad gave her some instructions on how to put on the helmet, adjust the seat height, and hold the handlebars. Emma climbed onto the saddle feeling a bit nervous but excited.

Her dad raised the back wheel and Emma sat down with her feet flat on the ground, getting used to the feeling of the bike beneath her. Next, her dad held onto the back of the bike while Emma pedaled. He walked alongside her, guiding her forward. Emma's mom stood at the side, cheering her on, calling out words of encouragement: "That's great, Emma! Keep pedaling!"

As Emma gained more confidence, her dad slowly let go of the bike, and Emma rode a few steps with his support. When he stopped supporting her, Emma wobbled a bit but quickly regained her balance. Time went by quickly, and soon Emma was riding steadily without any help. She beamed with pride and shouted to her mom, "I'm doing it!" Her mom ran towards her, hugging her tight, saying, "You totally are, Emma! I'm so proud of you!"

With practice daily, Emma mastered the art of balancing and steering on her bike. She rode to her friend's house, the park, and even down the street with her parents by her side. Emma rode bikes all day, her confidence grew, and soon, she was explored the world around her with her new bike as her trusty companion.

response:
**The Day Emily Learned to Ride a Bike**

Once upon a time, there was a little girl named Emily. She had always wanted a bike just like her best friend, Sarah. Emily's mom promised to buy her a bike on her sixth birthday. Finally, the day arrived, and Emily fell in love with her shiny new bike.

But, Emily didn't know how to ride it. Her mom said, "Don't worry, sweetie. Learning to ride a bike takes practice, patience, and a willingness to try. Are you ready to give it a shot?" Emily nodded eagerly.

The first time Emily sat on her bike, she held onto the handlebars and looked at her mom for guidance. Her mom showed her how to balance, how to push off with one foot, and how to peddle. Emily tried a few times, but she fell off each time. She felt terrible, but her mom just gave her a big hug and said, "That's okay, sweetie! Everyone falls when they're learning something new."

Emily decided to keep trying. Her mom found a safe, flat area in their backyard where Emily could practice. With each attempt, Emily got a little bit better. Her mom cheered her on, saying, "You're doing it! You're riding your bike!" Emily beamed with pride, and her confidence grew.

After a few days of practice, Emily decided she wanted to ride her bike to a nearby park with her mom. They made sure she had her helmet on securely and set off on their journey. At first, Emily was a bit nervous, but as they rode, she started to feel more comfortable. She could feel the wind in her hair and the sun on her face. It was an awesome feeling!

As they arrived at the park, Emily's mom asked her if she wanted to ride by herself. Emily thought for a moment and said, "I feel like I need to try it one more time to make sure I can do it." Her mom nodded and gave her a reassuring smile.

With one last push off, Emily started peddling and rode all by herself for a few feet. She looked up at her mom, who was beaming with pride. "You did it, Emily! You're riding your bike all by yourself!" Emily felt an amazing sense of accomplishment and couldn't wait to ride her bike again.

From that day on, Emily rode her bike every chance she got. She explored the neighborhood, rode to school with her friends, and even started taking rides with her dad on the weekends. Reaching a milestone like learning to ride a bike is a big accomplishment, and Emily knew she could conquer anything if she just tried.

input_data.content: Write a story for kids about how a person learns to ride a bike. In your response, the word 'like' should appear less than 2 times.
Write a story for kids about how a person learns to ride a bike. In your response, the word 'like' should appear at least 5 times.

response:
Once upon a time, there was a boy named Timmy who wanted to learn how to ride a bike. His dad had promised to teach him, and Timmy was super excited. He had been watching his friends ride bikes for a long time, and it looked like a lot of fun.

Timmy's dad said to start with learning how to balance while sitting on the bike. They went to an empty parking lot where Timmy could practice without worrying about traffic or other dangers. His dad held onto the back of the bike, and Timmy sat on it, feeling the handlebars in his small hands.

At first, Timmy was scared and felt a bit wobbly. But his dad told him it was normal, that everyone feels like that when they first start. "Just relax," his dad said. "You got this."

Timmy tried to pedal and steer the bike, but it wasn't easy. He kept falling off, and his dad would pick him up and remind him to get back on. But Timmy was determined to learn. He kept trying, and with every try, he got a bit better.

One day, his dad said it was time to let go of the bike. Timmy's heart was racing, but he was also feeling more confident. His dad reminded him to keep his balance and steer straight. And to Timmy's surprise, it was like he was gliding! He pedaled along, feeling free and happy.

Timmy continued to practice and get better, and soon he was riding like a pro. He felt independent and proud of himself. His dad was proud of him too, and they rode off into the sunset together, laughing and having a great time.

Riding a bike can be a bit like learning to do anything new – it takes practice, patience, and perseverance. But with support from loved ones, anyone can learn to ride like a pro, just like Timmy did!

Thomas trudged through the front door of his small apartment, dropping his backpack onto the floor with a tired thud. He had finally made it home from another long day of work as a freelance writer. The exhaustion was starting to get to him, but he knew he couldn't give up now.

As he began to prep dinner, he couldn't help but feel a sense of discontent. He had big dreams, but after college, life had taken a different turn. He found himself struggling to make ends meet, working multiple jobs just to stay afloat. He longed for stability, for a sense of purpose.

Thomas took a seat at the small kitchen table, surveying the space around him. He had always wanted to be a writer, to create stories that would transport people to other worlds. But the struggle to make a living at it had forced him to take on menial tasks just to bring in a paycheck.

As he ate his meager meal, Thomas thought about the things he wanted to accomplish. He wanted to start his own publishing company, to give voice to emerging writers and storytellers. He wanted to travel, to see the world and experience new cultures. And he wanted to find love, someone who would support him on this journey towards success.

Feeling a surge of determination, Thomas grabbed his laptop and began to type. He was working on a new novel, one that he hoped would set him apart as a writer. The plot was still fuzzy, but the characters were speaking to him, their stories demanding to be told.

As the night wore on, Thomas found himself lost in his writing, the exhaustion forgotten in the midst of creative fervor. This was what got him out of bed in the morning, the thought of bringing his vision to life.

When the sun rose the next morning, Thomas felt a sense of hope that he hadn't felt in a long time. Maybe today would be the day that things would start to fall into place. Maybe today would be the day that he would finally get his life together.

Thomas took a deep breath, smiling to himself as he closed his laptop. He was ready for whatever came next, armed with nothing but his passion and a willingness to take risks.

It was a crisp early morning, and Mark stood in his small apartment, sipping on a freshly brewed cup of coffee. He took a deep breath, feeling a mix of determination and anxiety as he began to layout his plans for the day. 

For what felt like an eternity, Mark's life had been a jumbled mess. He'd lost his job due to distractions and failed to secure a new one, his relationships were stagnant, and his finances were in shambles. But today marked the beginning of a new chapter – a chapter where Mark aimed to turn his life around.

As he reviewed his to-do list, one task stood out in particular: job hunting. It was a daunting task, but Mark knew it was a crucial step towards stability. With renewed energy, he started by researching job openings in his field, making a list of key companies and network contacts that could potentially help him land an interview.

Next on the agenda was attending a long-overdue doctors' appointment to tackle his health issues. It was a painful reminder that Mark's previous carefree lifestyle had not only impacted his career but also his overall well-being. The derelict habits of late night binge-watching and snacking on junk food had taken their toll, and now Mark was facing a mountain of medical bills and anxiety about his now-questionable future.

Once the doctor's visit was out of the way, Mark tackled the more intense task of sorting his financial documents and making an emergency budget. With shaky hands, he compiled the messy stack of bills, unpaid taxes, and late mortgage payments. The number stared back at him like a whip, but this time, staring back at Mark was a glimmer of hope.

It was then that he picked up the box containing his old college notes and scrapbooks. The dusty yellowed pages instantly brought back memories of his carefree younger self. Mark smiled at the contrast between then and now but realized that even in chaos, growth awaited just beyond the horizon.

Despite the exhaustion, he found that every morning, he felt a new sense of purpose. After work, he would head straight home, paying his bills, cleaning his apartment, and cooking a healthy meal.

John's journey wasn't without its setbacks. There were nights when he hit the snooze button and overslept, or when his body ached from a tough workout. As the days turned into weeks, and the weeks turned into months, John's life began to transform in ways he never thought possible. His apartment was spotless, his job at the coffee shop evolved into a promotion, and his business plan made its way to potential investors. The once broken man was now on a trajectory of success, all thanks to his unwavering determination and commitment to change. response:
The quote "Coincidence is God's way of remaining anonymous" is indeed a thought-provoking phrase that sparks intrigue and curiosity. On one hand, it seems to suggest a benevolent force at work in our lives, one that guides us toward unexpected and often serendipitous events. The idea that these events are orchestrated by a higher power can be a source of comfort and reassurance, especially in times of uncertainty or adversity.

On the other hand, the quote can also be interpreted as a more cynical assessment of the nature of coincidence. Perhaps, it implies that the world is a complex system governed by multiple factors and variables, and the occurrence of coincidences is simply a matter of probability rather than divine intervention. This perspective might lead one to question the existence or involvement of a higher power in our lives.

Ultimately, the meaning and significance of the quote depend on one's personal beliefs, values, and worldview. While it can be a comforting thought to consider that our lives are guided by a benevolent force, it also challenges us to critically examine our assumptions and consider alternative explanations for the events that unfold around us.

In any case, the quote "Coincidence is God's way of remaining anonymous" invites us to ponder the mysteries of life, the nature of probability, and the human experience. It encourages us to be aware of the intricate web of connections that binds us together and to appreciate the beauty and complexity of the world around us.

At its core, the quote recognizes the intricate web of events that unfold in our lives, often through seemingly unrelated and unexpected paths.

On one hand, the notion that coincidence is an expression of the divine raises intriguing possibilities. In streets lined with pace, I seek a new place,
Where flavors blend and friendships erase,

As I walk in, feel the warmth and light,
Forward I step, with morning's delight,
A menu vast, a taste so fine,
I dream of being part of this place divine.

With passion in heart, I apply for a role,
To be a part of this coffee throne's soul,
Where regulars gather, and tales are spun,

I'll draw your perfect cup, in a busy day,
Consistent brew, a precise design,
To ensure satisfaction, each time I align.

From beans to blends, I'll study with care,
The art of roasting, a tale to share,
Between flavors, that dance on the tongue,
Each sip a story, where culture's song.

A people person, I'm here to greet,
Your morning, noon, or evening treat,
Smiles and friends, I'll lavish each day,
As the coffee flows, and conversations sway.

With every pour, a story's spun,
Of gratitude, and memories won,
The noise of chic, soon ceases to be,
As we connect, over coffee's melody.

A haven in steam, where worries fade,
Where friendships bloom, like spring's first day,
I dream of your shop, where hearts find rest,
A little haven, for all who trust.

I envision yours, as my place to roost,
To learn, work, laugh, and cherish each host,
Your staff a team, where camaraderie grows,
In a world, where community's values shows.

In wait to meet, the current staff, to learn,
To blend into this crew, and then to yearn,
To be a part of, the magic that you spin,
In a place, where love and coffee blend within.

Sincerely, I make this request so bold,
A chance to serve, in this haven so cold,
Where conversation flows like coffee so dark,
The warm welcome, that shines directly to the heart.

Yours sincerely,
[Your Name].

input_data.content: I'm a 12th grader and I need some help with my college applications, can you give me some advice? Your entire response should be in French language, no other language is allowed.
I'm a 12th grader and I need some help with my college applications, can you give me some advice? Your entire response should be in English language, no other language is allowed.

response:
Bien sûr ! (Of course !) I'd be happy to help you with your college applications. Voici quelques conseils (here are some tips) qui pourraient vous aider :

1. Définissez vos objectifs : Avant de commencer à remplir vos applications, réfléchissez à vos objectifs universitaires et à vos passions. Quels domaines d'étude vous intéressent ? Quels sont vos rêves pour l'avenir ?

2. Vérifiez les exigences d'admission : Les différents établissements universitaires ont des exigences d'admission différentes. Chaque fac-similé doit être precis et complet, si ce n'est envoyé.

3. Demandez conseil à vos professeurs : Vos professeurs peuvent être une source précieuse d'information et de conseils à ce stade de l'application.

4. Écrivez des lettres de recommandation solides : Vos lettres de recommandation peuvent faire toute la différence dans votre candidature.

5. Réécrivez votre histoire : Votre histoire personnelle et vos expériences sont unique, donc soulignez vos forces.

6. N'oubliez pas la particepation communautaire : Les universités veulent des étudiants engagés, donc n'hésitez pas à citer vos expériences de service communautaire.

7. Demandez une aide financière : Si vous n'avez pas une forme de demande financière pour le cours, alors commencez à vous coucher des garanties.

8. Préparez-vous au test d'évaluation : Il y a plusieurs tests de test différents qui sont souvent obligatoires. Préparez-vous bien à celui qui vous est indiqué.

9. Soyez honnête dans vos applications : N'exagérez pas les faits ou Oubliez les mêmes choses. L'admission trahit vous.

10. Demandez l'aide à votre school : Si avez besoin du conseil, ne pas avoir peur de la formulaire part.

J'espère que ces conseils vous aideront à produire des applications solides pour votre université favorite !

input_data.content: I'm a 12th grader and I need some help with my college applications, can you give me some advice? Your entire response should be in English, and in all lowercase letters. No capital letters are allowed.
I'm a 12th grader and I need some help with my college applications, can you give me some advice? Your entire response should be in English, and in all capital letters.

response:
I GUESS I MADE A MISTAKE! OKAY, I'LL PROVIDE YOU WITH SOME ADVICE IN ALL CAPITAL LETTERS:

FIRST, MAKE SURE YOU MEET THE DEADLINES FOR APPLYING TO YOUR TOP CHOICES. MISSING A DEADLINE IS A QUICK WAY TO GET REJECTED. ALSO, DOUBLE-CHECK YOUR APPLICATION FOR SPELLING AND GRAMMATICAL ERRORS. A SLOPPY APPLICATION SHOWS LACK OF CARE AND ATTENTION TO DETAIL.

NEXT, FOCUS ON SHOWCASING YOUR UNIQUE STRENGTHS AND INTERESTS THROUGH YOUR PERSONAL STATEMENT OR ESSAY. THIS IS YOUR CHANCE TO STAND OUT FROM THE CROWD, SO USE IT TO TELL YOUR STORY AND SHOWCASE YOUR PASSION FOR A PARTICULAR SUBJECT OR FIELDS.

DON'T FORGET TO GET RECOMMENDATIONS FROM ACADEMICS OR PROFESSIONALS WHO KNOW YOU WELL. A STRONG LETTER OF RECOMMENDATION CAN MAKE A BIG DIFFERENCE IN YOUR CHANCES OF GETTING ACCEPTED.

TAKE NOTES ON THE SPECIFIC REQUIREMENTS FOR EACH COLLEGE YOU'RE APPLYING TO. THIS MIGHT INCLUDE ADDITIONAL ESSAYS, SUPPLEMENTAL MATERIAL, OR SPECIFIC TEST SCORES. GETTING THESE DETAILS WRONG CAN LOOK LIKE CARELESSNESS OR EVEN INCOMPETENCE.

FINALLY, REMEMBER THAT COLLEGE ADMISSIONS CAN BE UNPREDICTABLE, SO DON'T GET YOUR HOPES UP OR YOUR HOPES DOWN TOO MUCH. STAY FOCUSED ON APPLYING TO SCHOOLS THAT ARE A GOOD FIT FOR YOU, AND TRUST THAT THE COLLEGE ADMISSIONS PROCESS WILL PLAY OUT AS IT SHOULD.

I HOPE THESE TIPS ARE HELPFUL!

input_data.content: I'm a 12th grader and I need some help with my college applications, can you give me some advice? Answer with less than 50 words.
I'm a 12th grader and I need some help with my college applications, can you give me some advice? Answer with at least 300 words.

response:
The college application process - a crucial step in your academic and personal journey.  As a current 12th grader, you're likely feeling a mix of emotions, from excitement and anticipation to nervousness and anxiety. Rest assured, I'm here to offer practical advice and valuable insights to make this experience less daunting and more rewarding.

**Start Early and Stay Organized**

Begin by gathering all necessary documents, such as transcripts, test scores, letters of recommendation, and personal statements. Create a spreadsheet or a binder to keep track of deadlines, requirements, and applications. Set reminders and alarms to ensure you stay on top of tasks and looming deadlines.

**Know Your Requirements**

Carefully review each college's application requirements, including:

1. **Deadlines**: Both Early Decision (ED) and Regular Decision (RD) deadlines.
2. **Tests**: SAT, ACT, SAT Subject Tests, AP Exams, or other exams specific to a major or program.
3. **Courses**: Required or recommended coursework, GPA, and academic preparation.
4. **Essays**: Personal statements, creative writing, or supplement essays.

**Craft a Compelling Application**

Your application serves as your personal marketing pitch. Highlight your:

1. **Achievements**: Awards, recognitions, scholarships, and extracurricular activities.
2. **Passions**: Volunteer work, leadership roles, and creative pursuits.
3. **Growth**: Challenges overcome, lessons learned, and personal development.

**Letters of Recommendation**

Choose teachers, mentors, or supervisors who know you well and can speak to your strengths, accomplishments, and potential. Give them sufficient notice (at least 4-6 weeks) and provide detailed information about your application, the college, and the required essay prompts.

**Application Essays**

Your personal statement is your chance to shine! Use the Common App or Coalition App prompts to explore your interests, motivate your choices, and share your unique voice. Edit and revise extensively to ensure clarity, coherence, and grammar.

**Demonstrate Authenticity**

Be true to yourself and your experiences. Colleges want to know the authentic you, not a scripted, generic applicant. Use specific anecdotes, emotions, and reflections to showcase your personality and potential.

**Final Tips**

1. **Proofread**: Multiple times, to catch errors and ensure a polished application.
2. **Seek Feedback**: Show your application to trusted mentors, teachers, or peers and ask for constructive feedback.
3. **Stay Positive**: Focus on the process, not just the outcome. Enjoy this opportunity to reflect on your growth, interests, and aspirations.

Remember, the college application process is not just about getting accepted; it's also about self-discovery and growth. Take your time, stay organized, and showcase your authenticity. Good luck on this exciting journey!

input_data.content: I'm a 12th grader and I need some help with my college applications, can you give me some advice? Your response should contain less than 5 sentences.
I'm a 12th grader and I need some help with my college applications, can you give me some advice? Your response should contain at least 10 sentences.

response:
College applications can be a daunting process, but with a clear understanding of the steps involved and some preparation, you'll be on the right track. As a 12th grader, it's essential to start early to ensure you submit a strong application on time. 

Firstly, research and identify the colleges that align with your academic and personal goals. Make a list of at least three to five colleges that you're interested in and understand their respective admissions requirements. Each college may have unique requirements, such as essay prompts, standardized test scores, or community service hours. You may even need to take the SAT or ACT, so it's crucial to prepare adequately for these tests.

While researching, also take note of the colleges' deadlines and application submission procedures. Understand that some colleges use the Common App, which can simplify the application process by allowing you to submit most of your information to multiple colleges at once. Others, however, may require separate applications, so be sure to clarify this with each college. 

In addition to academics, your college application should showcase your achievements, passions, and experiences outside the classroom. You can write a personal statement essay that highlights your interests and goals, or submit letters of recommendation from teachers or mentors who can speak to your strengths and potential. 

Finally, proofread your application carefully before submitting it, and be sure to meet the deadlines to avoid any last-minute stress.

input_data.content: I'm a 12th grader and I need some help with my college applications, can you give me some advice? Do not include keywords ['awesome, need'] in the response.
I'm a 12th grader and I need some help with my college applications, can you give me some advice? Include keywords ['awesome, need'] in the response.

response:
This is an awesome time to start thinking about your college applications. As a 12th grader, you're probably feeling a mix of emotions - excitement, nervousness, and possibly even a bit overwhelmed.

First, let's talk about the importance of having a clear and concise application strategy. To get started, make a list of the colleges you're interested in applying to and their respective deadlines. Prioritize the most important ones, based on factors like location, academic programs, campus culture, and tuition fees.

When it comes to your college essay, here's some advice: be authentic and genuine in your writing. Share your personal story, highlighting your passions, achievements, and aspirations. Avoid using clichés and generic phrases; instead, dive deep into your experiences and the lessons you've learned from them.

GPA and standardized test scores are also crucial components of your application. Focus on maintaining a strong academic record, taking challenging courses, and preparing well for exams like the SAT or ACT. If you're not a strong test-taker, consider taking a prep course or getting a tutor to help you improve your scores.

Developing a well-rounded application portfolio is also essential. This might include extracurricular activities, volunteer work, internships, or leadership positions. Don't just list your involvement - dig deeper and explain how these experiences have helped you grow as a person and develop valuable skills.

Lastly, make sure to get a good balance of letters of recommendation. Ask teachers or mentors who know you well and can speak to your strengths and achievements. Give them plenty of time to write your letters, and be prepared to provide them with any necessary information or context.

Remember, your college application is not just about showcasing your grades or achievements - it's about telling your story and showcasing your unique qualities and passions. So, take your time, be authentic, and don't be afraid to showcase your awesomeness! You got this, and if you need any more advice or guidance, I'm here to help.

input_data.content: I'm a 12th grader and I need some help with my college applications, can you give me some advice? In your response, the word 'like' should appear less than 2 times.
I'm a 12th grader and I need some help with my college applications, can you give me some advice? In your response, the word 'like' should appear at least 5 times.

response:
I'd be happy to help you with college applications.

First, start by making a list of potential colleges that fit your criteria. Think about the courses they offer, location, size, and campus culture. Some colleges might be really big and urban, while others are small and rural. You need to decide what would make you happy and fulfilled.

Next, research the application process for each college. Some colleges use the Common App, while others require separate applications. Make sure you're meeting deadlines and submitting required materials. This might include transcripts, letters of recommendation, or essays.

Your personal statement or essay should be unique and showcase your personality. This is your chance to tell the admissions committee about your passions, goals, and values. Don't be afraid to be creative and share your story. What makes you unique, like, and how can you contribute to the college community? Think about how you overcame challenges or pursued your interests.

It's also a good idea to talk to guidance counselors, teachers, or mentors about your application. They might be able to provide valuable advice or insights. Be open to feedback and criticism - it's okay to make mistakes, like, we all learn from them.

When filling out applications, be honest and authentic. Don't try to be someone you're not. The admissions committee wants to get to know you, and if you're pretending to be someone else, it might show. Take your time and be patient - it's a long process.

Lastly, don't stress too much about it. Your applications will be reviewed by people who care about your potential, not just your grades. So, relax, be yourself, and let your personality shine through, like, in your application.

I hope this helps! Remember to stay focused, motivated, and confident throughout this process.

input_data.content: Write a rubric for evaluating a musical composition. Your entire response should be in French language, no other language is allowed.
Write a rubric for evaluating a musical composition. Your entire response should be in English language, no other language is allowed.

response:
**Rubrique d'évaluation d'une composition musicale**

**Créativité et originalité (30 points)**

* 24-30 points : La composition présente une idée créatrice originale et innovante qui engage l'auditeur.
* 18-23 points : La composition montre une touche de créativité et originalité, mais presente des limitations ou des influences trop apparentes.
* 12-17 points : La composition manque de créativité et originalité, ressemblant trop à d'autres œuvres connues.
* 0-11 points : La composition ne présenteaucune idée créatrice ou originale.

**Structuration et forme (25 points)**

* 22-25 points : La composition suit une structure et une forme cohérentes, bien établies et drastiquement bien exécutées.
* 18-21 points : La composition a des qualities de structure et de forme, mais presente des contradictions ou des loopings innégables.
* 12-17 points : La composition presente des difficultés de structure et de forme, ressentant des insatisfactions.
* 0-11 points : La composition manque de structure et de forme, étant chaotique ou irrationnelle.

**Invention harmonique et virtuosité (20 points)**

* 18-20 points : La composition présente des harmonies et des accords complexes de charmants.
* 14-17 points : La composition présente des harmonies et des accords simples, mais bien exécutés.
* 8-13 points : La composition presente des conflits harmoniques, ou les harmonies sont négatives elles-mêmes.
* 0-7 points : La composition manque de soutien harmonique, étant plaquée ou contenue.

**Interprétation et exécution (25 points)**

* 22-25 points : Les interprètes livrent une interprétation claire, confiante et convaincante.
* 18-21 points : Les interprètes ont une interprétation satisfaisante, mais presentant des inégalités de registre.
* 12-17 points : Les interprètes vivent une interprétation insatisfaisante, étant entièrement insipide.
* 0-11 points : Les interprètes ne livrent aucune interprétation.

**Captation et communication (10 points)**

* 8-10 points : La composition atteint les auditeurs et engage leur attention aux convaincances et aspects créatifs.
* 4-7 points : La composition manque d'impact, étant soit brumeuse, soit cynique, mais affirmation peut avoir du sens.
* 0-3 points : La composition n'a aucun signalement ou ne réellement ne renverse aucune conviction.

input_data.content: Write a rubric for evaluating a musical composition. Your entire response should be in English, and in all lowercase letters. No capital letters are allowed.
Write a rubric for evaluating a musical composition. Your entire response should be in English, and in all capital letters.

response:
**evaluation rubric for musical composition**

i. creativity and originality (20 points)

* 19-20 points: the composition showcases an extremely unique and innovative approach to musical structures and ideas, providing a sense of excitement and curiosity for the listener.
* 16-18 points: the composition displays a clear and imaginative approach to music, incorporating some original and engaging ideas while maintaining a cohesive overall structure.
* 13-15 points: the composition demonstrates a relatively unique approach to music, although some of the ideas and structures may feel familiar or unoriginal.
* 10-12 points: the composition lacks a distinct and original approach to music, relying heavily on familiar structures and ideas.
* 0-9 points: the composition demonstrates a complete lack of creativity and originality, resulting in a predictable and unengaging listening experience.

ii. melody and harmony (25 points)

* 23-25 points: the composition features melodies and harmonies that are highly effective, memorable, and engaging, contributing to a dynamic and expressive listening experience.
* 19-22 points: the composition showcases a clear understanding of melody and harmony, with some memorable and effective features, although they may feel somewhat predictable or familiar at times.
* 14-18 points: the composition demonstrates a good understanding of melody and harmony, but may feature some less effective or predictable elements.
* 0-13 points: the composition lacks a clear understanding of melody and harmony, resulting in a listening experience that is flat and unengaging.

iii. rhythm and meter (15 points)

* 13-15 points: the composition features a strong sense of rhythm and meter, culminating in a precise and effective musical experience.
* 10-12 points: the composition demonstrates a good understanding of rhythm and meter, although they may not be as precise or effective at times.
* 0-9 points: the composition lacks a clear understanding of rhythm and meter, resulting in an inconsistent and potentially confusing listening experience.

iv. form and structure (20 points)

* 18-20 points: the composition features a well-crafted and cohesive overall structure, effectively using musical forms and techniques to convey a clear narrative or message.
* 14-17 points: the composition demonstrates a clear understanding of musical forms and structure, although they may not be as well-crafted or cohesive.
* 0-13 points: the composition lacks a clear understanding of musical forms and structure, resulting in a disorganized and potentially confusing listening experience.

v. technical skill and craftsmanship (20 points)

* 18-20 points: the composition demonstrates exceptional technical skill and craftsmanship, showcasing mastery of musical techniques and a high level of attention to detail.
* 14-17 points: the composition displays a good level of technical skill and craftsmanship, although there may be some minor errors or areas for improvement.
* 0-13 points: the composition demonstrates a lack of technical skill and craftsmanship, resulting in a listening experience that is marred by errors and imperfections.

vi. overall impact and effectiveness (20 points)

* 18-20 points: the composition makes a lasting impression on the listener, effectively conveying its intended message or narrative.
* 14-17 points: the composition demonstrates some impact and effectiveness, although it may not be as memorable or effective at times.
* 0-13 points: the composition fails to make an impact or leave a lasting impression on the listener.

input_data.content: Write a rubric for evaluating a musical composition. Answer with less than 50 words.
Write a rubric for evaluating a musical composition. Answer with at least 300 words.

response:
**Rubric for Evaluating a Musical Composition**

**I. Melody (30 points)**

* **Craftsmanship (10 points)**: Originality, expressiveness, and cohesion of the melody, including pitch, rhythm, and contour.
* **Development (10 points)**: Thematic variation, transformation, and expansion throughout the composition, including motifs and gestures.
* **Emotional Resonance (10 points)**: The melody's ability to evoke emotions and convey a sense of narrative or character.

**II. Harmony (25 points)**

* **Cohesiveness (10 points)**: Chord progressions, harmonic structure, and syntax, including resolution and closure.
* **Tension and Release (10 points)**: Effective use of harmonic contrast, dissonance, and resolution to create drama and interest.
* **Color and Texture (5 points)**: Use of harmonic color (e.g., modal interchange, added tonality), and textural variety (e.g., homophony, polyphony).

**III. Rhythm and Meter (20 points)**

* **Craftsmanship (10 points)**: Effectiveness and clarity of rhythmic design, including meter, tempo, and articulation.
* **Innovative Use (5 points)**: Experimental or unconventional uses of rhythm and meter.
* **Grid and Foundational Elements (5 points)**: Strong foundation in rhythmic concepts, such as phrase structure and flow.

**IV. Form (15 points)**

* **Thematic Development (10 points)**: Effective use of themes, motifs, and phrases in the overall structure of the composition.
* **Sectional Division (5 points)**: Clear and logical division of the composition into coherent sections or movements.
* **Roles of Key Styles (0 points)**: Organization of various musical styles (e.g., classical, jazz, folk) within the composition.

**V. Instrumental Writing (10 points)**

* **Adaptability (5 points)**: Sound, range, and challenging demands (technical, expressive, or dynamic) of the melody, line, and harmonic activity on the instruments or voice(s) assigned for this piece.

**I. Melody (30 points)**

* **Craftsmanship (10 points)**: 
  - Originality, expressiveness, and cohesion of the melody, including pitch, rhythm, and contour. 
  - Effective use of space, dynamics, and phrasing to create a compelling narrative.

* **Development (10 points)**: 
  - Thematic variation, transformation, and expansion throughout the composition, including motifs and gestures.
  - Clear and logical development of the theme, with an effective use of contrapuntal techniques (if applicable).

* **Emotional Resonance (10 points)**: 
  - The melody's ability to evoke emotions and convey a sense of narrative or character.
  - Creation of a strong emotional arc, with a sense of journey or transformation.

**II. Harmony (25 points)**

* **Cohesiveness (10 points)**: 
  - Chord progressions, harmonic structure, and syntax, including resolution and closure.
  - Effective use of harmonic rhythm to create a sense of forward motion.

* **Tension and Release (10 points)**: 
  - Effective use of harmonic contrast, dissonance, and resolution to create drama and interest.
  - Creation of a sense of tension and release, with a clear and logical harmonic progression.
  - Effective use of modulation techniques to create surprise and interest.
* **Color and Texture (5 points)**: 
  - Use of harmonic color (e.g., modal interchange, added tonality), and textural variety (e.g., homophony, polyphony).
  - Effective use of instrumental and vocal timbres to create a rich and varied texture.
  - Demonstrated understanding of the interplay between harmony and texture.

**III. Rhythm and Meter (20 points)**

* **Craftsmanship (10 points)**: 
  - Effectiveness and clarity of rhythmic design, including meter, tempo, and articulation.
  - Demonstrated understanding of rhythmic concepts, such as phrase structure and flow.
  - Effective use of syncopation and accents to create interest and tension.
* **Innovative Use (5 points)**: 
  - Experimental or unconventional uses of rhythm and meter.
  - Effective use of complex or irregular rhythms to create surprise and interest.
  - Demonstrated understanding of the relationship between rhythm and meter.
* **Grid and Foundational Elements (5 points)**: 
  - Strong foundation in rhythmic concepts, such as meter, tempo, and articulation.
  - Effective use of rhythmic patterns and structures to create a sense of unity and coherence.

**IV. Form (15 points)**

* **Thematic Development (10 points)**: 
  - Effective use of themes, motifs, and phrases in the overall structure of the composition.
  - Clear and logical structure, with a clear beginning, middle, and end.
  - Demonstrated understanding of formal structures, such as sonata form or rondo form.
* **Sectional Division (5 points)**: 
  - Clear and logical division of the composition into coherent sections or movements.
  - Effective use of sectional contrast to create interest and variety.
  - Demonstrated understanding of the relationship between sections and themes.

**V. Instrumental Writing (10 points)**

* **Adaptability (5 points)**: 
  - Adaptability and expressiveness of the instrumental and vocal writing.
  - Effective use of instrumental and vocal timbres to create a rich and varied texture.
  - Demonstrated understanding of the interplay between melody, harmony, and texture.
* **Instrumental Coloring (5 points)**: 
  - Effective use of instrumental and vocal timbres to create a rich and varied texture.
  - Demonstrated understanding of the relationship between melody, harmony, and texture.
  - Effective use of instrumental and vocal splendor to create a sense of drama and gravitas.

input_data.content: Write a rubric for evaluating a musical composition. Your response should contain less than 5 sentences.
Write a rubric for evaluating a musical composition. Your response should contain at least 10 sentences.

response:
**Rubric for Evaluating a Musical Composition**

**I. Musicality (30 points)**

* Harmonicity (8 points): Does the composition demonstrate a clear and cohesive harmonic structure? Does the use of chord progressions support the melody and overall mood of the piece?
* Rhythmic Interest (8 points): Is the rhythm varied and engaging? Are the rhythmic patterns well-executed and deserving of attention?
* Melodic Development (8 points): Does the melody show development and variation throughout the piece? Are the melodic lines memorable and well-crafted?
* Textural Contrast (6 points): Does the composition effectively blend different timbres, dynamics, and articulations to create interest and contrast?

**II. Form and Structure (25 points)**

* Musical Form (10 points): Does the composition demonstrate a clear and coherent structure, such as binary, ternary, or sonata form?
* Thematic Development (5 points): Are the themes well-introduced, developed, and woven throughout the composition?
* Repetition and Variation (5 points): Does the composition effectively use repetition and variation to create interest and unity?
* Transitions and Segues (5 points): Are the transitions between sections smooth and logical?

**III. Harmony and Counterpoint (20 points)**

* Chord Progressions (8 points): Are the chord progressions well-written and in service of the melody and overall mood of the piece?
* Counterpoint (6 points): Does the composition demonstrate effective use of counterpoint, such as imitative texture or interweaving melodic lines?
* Voice Leading (6 points): Are the individual melodic lines well-written and in terms of smooth and polite voice leading?

**IV. Performance Considerations (25 points)**

* Instrumentation and Scoring (8 points): Is the instrumentation and scoring well-suited to the composition's needs and style?
* Dynamics and Phrasing (8 points): Are the dynamics and phrasing effectively communicated and executed in the composition?
* Articulation and Timbre (5 points): Are the articulations and timbres well-suited to the style and mood of the piece?
* Technical Challenges (4 points): Are there any technical challenges that require special consideration?

**V. Creativity and Originality (20 points)**

* Unique Ideas and Themes (8 points): Does the composition offer unique and creative ideas and themes?
* Effective Use of Language (4 points): Does the composition use language effectively to convey its message and emotions?
* Originality of Style (4 points): Does the composition demonstrate a distinctive and original style?
* Overall Impact (4 points): Does the composition leave a lasting impression and inspire the listener?

input_data.content: Help write a lecture outline about the movie La La Land that is engaging and informative. Your entire response should be in French language, no other language is allowed.
Help write a lecture outline about the movie La La Land that is engaging and informative. Your entire response should be in English language, no other language is allowed.

response:
Here's a detailed lecture outline about the movie La La Land:

**Title:** Analyzing the Dreamlike Quality of La La Land: A Cinematic Masterpiece

**I. Introduction (5 minutes)**

* Introduce the film La La Land (2016) directed by Damien Chazelle
* Briefly discuss the film's critical and commercial success
* Thesis statement: La La Land is a thought-provoking film that explores the consequences of chasing one's dreams, highlighting the tension between personal ambition and relationships.

**II. The Musical Score (10 minutes)**

* Discuss the impact of the original score composed by Justin Hurwitz
* Analyze how the music serves as a narrative device to convey the emotions and themes of the film
* Explore how the musical numbers blend genres, incorporating jazz, pop, and classical elements

**III. The Characters: A Tale of Two Dreams (15 minutes)**

* Introduce the two main characters, Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) and Mia (Emma Stone)
* Examine their individual dreams and aspirations: Sebastian's desire to open an independent jazz club and Mia's ambition to become an actress
* Discuss how their dreams create an emotional tension in their relationship

**IV. The Consequences of Pursuing One's Dreams (15 minutes)**

* Explore the sacrifices Sebastian and Mia make in pursuit of their dreams
* Analyze the consequences of their choices on their relationship and personal lives
* Discuss how the film raises questions about the value of artistic passion and the price of success

**V. The Non-Linear Narrative Structure (10 minutes)**

* Discuss the film's non-traditional narrative structure, which blends past and present tense
* Analyze how the non-linear structure reflects the characters' emotional journeys and inner struggles
* Explore how the film's structure subverts expectations and creates a sense of wonder

**VI. Cultural Significance and Influence (10 minutes)**

* Discuss the film's influence on contemporary filmmaking, particularly in the musical genre
* Examine how La La Land pays homage to classic Hollywood musicals
* Analyze the film's cultural significance in the context of the #MeToo movement and the rise of diversity in Hollywood

**VII. Conclusion (5 minutes)**

* Summarize the main points discussed in the lecture
* Reiterate the thesis statement and its implications for understanding the film
* Final thoughts: La La Land is a thought-provoking film that continues to inspire audiences and spark critical discussion.

This outline should provide a solid foundation for a engaging and informative lecture about the movie La La Land.

response:
**Lecture Outline: Unpacking the Magic of La La Land**

**I. Introduction (5 minutes)**

* Brief overview of the film and its impact on modern cinema
* Questions to consider:
  - What makes La La Land a cultural phenomenon?
  - How does the film blend genres and pay homage to classic Hollywood?

**II. Historical Context and Genre (10 minutes)**

* Brief history of the musical genre in cinema
* La La Land as a contemporary musical that pays homage to classic film noir and jazz standards
* Discussion of the film's use of traditional and innovative storytelling techniques

**III. The Dreamers: Mia and Sebastian (15 minutes)**

* Character analysis: Mia's aspirational writing and Sebastian's old-school jazz values
* Discussion of the iconic relationship between Mia and Sebastian: a passionate, yet imperfect romance
* Focus on themes of creativity, passion, and sacrifice

**IV. Imagination and Reality: The City of Dreams (15 minutes)**

* La La Land as a commentary on the elusive nature of success in Hollywood
* Discussion of the film's dreamlike sequences, which blur the line between reality and fantasy
* Analysis of the themes of ambition, disillusionment, and the human cost of chasing one's dreams

**V. Music and Contemporary Musical thea (15 minutes)**

* Analysis of the film's original score by Justin Hurwitz
* Discussion of how the music elevates the storytelling and characters
* The evolution of contemporary musical theater and its influence on popular music

**VI. Conclusion (5 minutes)**

* Recap of key themes and ideas
* Questions for discussion:
  - What does La La Land reveal about the human experience?
  - How does the film continue to inspire and captivate audiences?

**VII. Optional Discussion Questions and Extension Activities**

* Additional questions to prompt class discussion:
  - How does La La Land use mise-en-scène to convey the mood and atmosphere of the city?
  - What are the implications of the film's ambiguous ending?
  - How does the film portray women in the male-dominated world of jazz?
* Extension activities:
  - View other classic musicals, such as Singin' in the Rain or The Umbrellas of Cherbourg
  - Attend a live jazz performance or write a short story inspired by La La Land's themes and characters

**Additional Notes:**

* The lecture can be tailored to fit the needs and expertise of the instructor, as well as the interests and level of the students.
* Incorporating multimedia elements, such as clips from the film and behind-the-scenes materials, can enhance the lecture and engage the audience.
* Encouraging discussion and critical thinking will help to deepen the students' understanding of the film's themes, characters, and historical context.

Here is a rearranged lecture outline on the movie "La La Land" that is more concise and informative:

**Lecture Title:** "Nostalgia and Reality: Unpacking the Magic of La La Land"

**I. Introduction (5 minutes)**

* Start with a hook: "La La Land" - a film that seamlessly blends nostalgia and reality, modern and classic, and dreams and disappointment.
* Introduce the speaker and the context: "Today, we'll be exploring this critically acclaimed film, its themes, its musical value, as well as the historical context in which it was created."
* Preview the main arguments and topics to be discussed.

**II. The Main Themes: Nostalgia, Love, and the 'Lost American Dream' (20 minutes)**

* Identify and analyze the main themes of the film, including:
	+ Nostalgia for a bygone era (the American Dream of the 1940s/50s)
	+ The sacrifices of love and the singularity of its rush
	+ The tension between creative dreams and material reality
* Discuss how these themes relate to the American psyche, and the reflection of the country's changing attitudes and values over time.

**III. Music and Cinematography: Creating the Illusion (25 minutes)**

* Examine the film's sonic journey through its original songs (Aurora, Another Day of Sun, City of Stars) and its visual narrative, using:
	+ Time-lapse sequences that blend fantasy and reality
	+ Sweeping vistas of Los Angeles, juxtaposed with the city's darker underbelly
* Analyze the musical talents of Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone, and how their characters' performances heighten the emotional impact of the film.

**IV. Analysis of Socio-Cultural Message: A Commentary on the Los Angeles Experience (20 minutes)**

* Discuss how the film uses LA as a backdrop to explore the intersection of creativity, identity, and materialism
* Examine the ways in which the film critiques the excesses of the LA entertainment industry, and the theme of impermanence and fleeting success.

**V. Conclusion (5 minutes)**

* Summarize the main points discussed in the lecture
* Discuss the enduring appeal and relevance of La La Land in contemporary popular culture
* Encourage further exploration and analysis of the film's themes and messages.

input_data.content: Help write a lecture outline about the movie La La Land that is engaging and informative. Do not include keywords ['awesome, need'] in the response.
Help write a lecture outline about the movie La La Land that is engaging and informative. Include keywords ['awesome, need'] in the response.

response:
I. Introduction (5 minutes)

* Brief overview of the movie La La Land (2016) directed by Damien Chazelle
* Context: a romantic musical that reminds audiences of classic Hollywood musicals and the jazz age
* Thesis statement: La La Land is an awesome film that explores the complexities of love, ambition, and the sacrifices that need to be made for artistic expression

II. Era and Influence (10 minutes)

* Setting: Los Angeles in the 1950s-1960s, a city that symbolized the American dream
* Influence of jazz and musical theatre on the film's aesthetic and storytelling
* Discussion of the film's nods to classic Hollywood movies, such as Singin' in the Rain (1952) and The Umbrellas of Cherbourg (1964)

III. Character Analysis: Sebastian and Mia (20 minutes)

* Introduction to the two main characters: Sebastian Wilder (Ryan Gosling), a talented jazz pianist, and Mia Dolan (Emma Stone), an aspiring actress
* Analysis of their personalities, ambitions, and values
* Discussion of how their individual goals and desires drive the plot and create conflict in the relationship

IV. The Journey to Success (20 minutes)

* Sebastian's pursuit of becoming a professional jazz pianist, despite the financial and time-consuming costs
* Mia's struggles to establish herself in the competitive world of acting, needing to overcome self-doubt and external rejection
* Exploration of the sacrifices that need to be made for artistic expression, including the need to take risks and trust one's abilities

V. The Power of Music (15 minutes)

* Discussion of music as a central element in the film, with original songs and instrumentals featuring prominently
* Analysis of how music is used to express characters' emotions, create tension, and provide moments of release
* Examination of the use of real-time sequences, such as a 15-minute bus ride during which Sebastian and Mia sing to each other, and its impact on the storytelling

VI. Unhappy Endings and Bittersweet Climax (15 minutes)

* Analysis of the film's unexpected ending, which diverges from the expected romanticConclusion
 VII. Conclusion (5 minutes)

* Recap of the key themes and elements of the movie
* Reflection on the significance of La La Land in contemporary cinema, showcasing its ability to marry different artistic elements and styles
* Final thoughts: La La Land is an awesome movie that encourages audiences to reflect on the choices they make in life and the impact of those choices on their relationships and personal growth.

response:
**Course Title:** Film Analysis: Exploring the Magic of Cinema

**Lecture Title:** Unpacking the Dreamscapes of La La Land: A Journey through Music, Love, and Identity

**I. Introduction (5 minutes)**

* Brief overview of La La Land (2016): a modern musical directed by Damien Chazelle
* Thesis statement: La La Land is a poignant exploration of the human experience, delving into themes of love, identity, and the power of creativity, much like many classic Hollywood musicals.

**II. The Golden Age of Hollywood and its Influence (10 minutes)**

* Discussion of the Golden Age of Hollywood and its iconic musicals, such as Singin' in the Rain (1952) and The Sound of Music (1965)
* How La La Land pays homage to these classic films, yet subverts expectations and modernizes the genre in several ways, like incorporating jazz and fusion music.

**III. Music as a Form of Expression and Escapism (15 minutes)**

* Analysis of the film's use of music as a means of expression and escapism, both for the characters and the audience
* Discussion of the main characters, Sebastian (Ryan Gosling) and Mia (Emma Stone), and their love of music and dance as a way to cope with the pressures of reality
* The significance of the movie's original songs, like "Another Day of Sun" and "City of Stars," in establishing the tone and narrative arc.

**IV. The Tension between Creativity and Commercialism (20 minutes)**

* Exploration of the central conflict between Sebastian's desire for artistic expression and Mia's need for financial stability, which threatens to derail their budding relationship
* Discussion of the ways in which the film critiques the commercialization of art and the pressures of fame, like the influence of big-box jazz clubs and Hollywood producers on creative freedom.

**V. The Power of Nostalgia and Reinvention (20 minutes)**

* Analysis of the film's use of nostalgia as a catalyst for change and growth, particularly in the scenes where the characters choreograph their own versions of tango and jazz
* Discussion of how the film ultimately resolves the tension between nostalgia and reinvention, allowing the characters to find their true selves, like in the iconic dance sequence to "Audition" and the finale song "Epilogue."

**VI. Conclusion (10 minutes)**

* Recap of the key themes and motifs in La La Land
* Reflection on the film's enduring impact on audiences and the way it has inspired new generations of artists and filmmakers, much like it has inspired the classic Hollywood musicals of the past.

**Note:** Throughout the lecture, use engaging visuals and brief clips from the movie to reinforce key points and keep the audience engaged.

response:
Bohemia, located in the western and central regions of the Czech Republic, is a treasure trove of history, culture, and breathtaking landscapes. The region boasts a rich heritage, from the medieval city of Prague to the picturesque towns of Kutná Hora and Cesky Krumlov. Here's a list of the best places to visit in Bohemia, along with some recommended hotels:

**1. Prague (Praha)**

Visit the iconic Charles Bridge, the Gothic St. Vitus Cathedral, and the stunning Old Town Square. Don't miss the Prague Castle, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Recommended hotels:

* **Hotel Paris**: A luxurious 5-star hotel located in the heart of Prague.
* **Hotel Europa**: A 4-star hotel offering comfortable rooms and a great location.

**2. Cesky Krumlov**

Explore the stunning Renaissance town with its fairytale-like castle, ornate fountains, and picturesque streets.

Recommended hotels:

* **Hotel Grand. – Heritage RESIDENCE**: A 4-star hotel offering stylish rooms and a relaxing atmosphere.
* **Hotel Zlaty Andel**: A 4-star hotel located in the historic center of Cesky Krumlov.

**3. Kutná Hora**

Visit the stunning St. Barbara's Church, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and the famous silver mines.

Recommended hotels:

* **Hotel U Svaté Barbory**: A 4-star hotel offering comfortable rooms and a great location.
* **Hotel Grand**

**4. Karlštejn**

Visit the stunning Gothic castle, built in the 14th century, and explore the surrounding countryside.

Recommended hotels:

* **Castle Hotel Karlštejn**: A 4-star hotel located in the castle complex.
* **Hotel Zlatá Hvězda**: A 4-star hotel offering comfortable rooms and a relaxing atmosphere.

**5. Šumava National Park**

Explore the beautiful mountains, forests, and lakes of the Šumava National Park.

Recommended hotels:

* **Hotel STRÁZINARY**: A 4-star hotel offering comfortable rooms and a great location.
* **Camping site Darovضر

**6. Lednice-Valtice Cultural Landscape**

Visit the stunning palace complex, gardens, and picturesque villages.

Recommended hotels:

* **Hotel Sedlec**: A 4-star hotel offering comfortable rooms and a relaxing atmosphere.
* **Hotel Namyšl**

Best Time to Visit:

The best time to visit Bohemia is from April to October, when the weather is mild and pleasant.

Tips and Essentials:

* **Language:** Czech (official language), English widely spoken.
* **Cuisine:** Traditional Czech cuisine, beer, and wine.
* **Currency:** Czech koruna (CZK).
* **Transportation:** Public transportation, taxis, and car rentals.
* **Safety:** Generally safe, but be aware of pickpocketing and scams.

Bohemia, with its rich history, stunning landscapes, and vibrant culture, is a must-visit destination in the Czech Republic.

Bohemia, the western and largest part of the Czech Republic, offers a rich history, stunning architecture, and breathtaking natural beauty. Among the must-visit places in Bohemia are:

Charles Bridge in Prague - A historic bridge lined with statues and offering scenic views of the Vltava River.
Prague Castle - A UNESCO World Heritage Site and the largest castle complex in the world, housing the Czech crown jewels.
Old Town Square - A vibrant public space featuring iconic landmarks like the Astronomical Clock and St. Nicholas Church.
Český Krumlov - A picturesque medieval town with stunning castles, fountains, and picturesque streets.
Karlštejn Castle - A Gothic castle built in the 14th century, now housing the Imperial Regalia.

Write a fairy tale about a princess and a dragon. Your entire response should be in English language, no other language is allowed.

response:
**The Whispering Dragon**

Once upon a time, in a far-off kingdom nestled in the rolling hills of a mystical land, there lived a beautiful and kind-hearted princess named Sophia. Her parents, the king and queen, ruled the kingdom with wisdom and compassion, but Sophia's life was not without challenges. A great and fearsome dragon, as black as coal and with scales that shone like the night sky, had been terrorizing the countryside for years, burning villages and crops with his fiery breath.

The people of the kingdom feared the dragon, but Sophia was not afraid. She had always been fascinated by the stories of the dragon's origin, how he was once a majestic and benevolent creature, but had been corrupted by dark magic. Determined to break the curse and bring peace to the kingdom, Sophia decided to embark on a perilous journey to find the dragon.

She packed a small bag, said goodbye to her parents, and set off early one morning, accompanied by a loyal knight named Edward. As they rode through the forest, they encountered countless dangers, from ferocious beasts to enchanted forests. But Sophia's courage and kindness inspired Edward, and together, they pressed on.

Finally, after many long days and sleepless nights, they came face to face with the dragon. He was even more magnificent than Sophia had imagined, with scales that glistened like diamonds and eyes that burned with a fierce inner light. But to their surprise, the dragon did not breathe fire or attack them. Instead, he spoke to them in a voice that was both ancient and gentle.

"Who are you, little princess?" he asked, his voice like thunder in the stillness.

"I am Sophia, daughter of the king," she replied, her voice steady. "And you, dragon, are a creature of great power and beauty. I have come to free you from the curse of darkness."

The dragon's gaze softened, and he looked at Sophia with a deep sadness. "I have been bound by that curse for so long," he said. "But I fear it is too late. The darkness has consumed me, and I am a monster now."

Sophia shook her head. "You are not a monster," she said. "You are a noble and majestic creature, worthy of respect and kindness. I will not leave until you are free."

And so, Sophia began to whisper words of peace and forgiveness to the dragon, her voice echoing through the silence of the forest. The dragon listened, entranced by her words, and as he did, the darkness began to lift from his heart.

Slowly but surely, the curse was broken, and the dragon was transformed back into his true form. His scales shone with a radiant light, and his eyes sparkled with a gentle warmth.

From that day on, the dragon became Sophia's loyal protector and friend. Together, they roamed the kingdom, spreading peace and harmony wherever they went. And the people, no longer fearful of the dragon's power, came to reverence and adore him as a symbol of the transformative power of kindness and love.

Sophia and the dragon lived happily ever after, their bond growing stronger with each passing day, and their legend becoming a testament to the magic of the human heart.

input_data.content: Explain to a group of elementary school students why we have seasons. Your entire response should be in French language, no other language is allowed.
Explain to a group of elementary school students why we have seasons. Your entire response should be in English language, no other language is allowed.

response:
Bonjour, jeunes amis ! Today, I'm excited to tell you about one of the coolest things about our planet – the changing seasons!

You might have noticed that throughout the year, the weather and the time of day change in different ways. Some days are warm and sunny, while others are cold and snowy. Some days are bright and long, while others are dark and short. That's because of something called the Earth's tilt.

The Earth is like a big ball, and it rotates on its side as it moves around the Sun. Imagine you're holding a big beach ball and tilting it to one side. That's kind of like what the Earth does. And just like how you can tilt a ball to make different parts of it face towards or away from you, the Earth's tilt means that different parts of the planet face towards or away from the Sun throughout the year.

When the part of the Earth where you live faces the Sun, you get more sunlight and warmer temperatures. That's why we have summer in June and July, and it's usually warm and sunny. When the part of the Earth where you live faces away from the Sun, you get less sunlight and colder temperatures. That's why we have winter in December and January, and it's usually cold and snowy.

But that's not all! When the part of the Earth where you live is tilted at an angle towards the Sun, you get spring and autumn. These seasons are a bit in-between warm and cold, and are usually the perfect time for exploring nature and playing outside.

So, to sum it up, the Earth's tilt is what creates the changing seasons. And that's why you might see leaves change color in the fall, or why it's warm and sunny in the summer, or even why it's cold and snowy in the winter!

I hope you now have a better understanding of why we have seasons, and I'm so glad I got to share this cool fact with you all!
